postsData.content:
Stop Hoping for Luck‚ÄîStart Negotiating With Skill
7 Power Moves to Master Salary Negotiation

You know that feeling...
Heart racing, palms sweaty, afraid to ask for more.

Your hesitation isn't just fear.
It's years of conditioning holding you back.

Most people make these mistakes:
‚Üí Accepting the first offer
‚Üí Apologizing for asking
‚Üí Fearing rejection

But great negotiators aren't born.
They're built through strategy and practice.

7 Power Moves to Master Salary Negotiation:

1. Know Your Value
‚Ü≥ You undersell your worth because of uncertainty
‚Ü≥ Research market rates and articulate your achievements

2. Set Your Strategy
‚Ü≥ You accept first offers without a clear plan
‚Ü≥ Define your ideal range and minimum acceptable number

3. Master Your Message
‚Ü≥ You ramble when nervous about asking
‚Ü≥ Practice clear, confident responses for common objections

4. Take Your Time
‚Ü≥ You rush decisions fearing the offer will disappear
‚Ü≥ Take time to evaluate offers and prepare responses

5. See the Full Picture
‚Ü≥ You focus only on base salary
‚Ü≥ Consider the entire package: benefits, equity, and growth

6. Back Your Ask
‚Ü≥ You make requests without a compelling case
‚Ü≥ Use market data and performance metrics to justify value

7. Own Your Power
‚Ü≥ You fear walking away from bad offers
‚Ü≥ Know your worth and be ready to decline


Salary negotiation isn't just about money.

It's about recognizing your value

postsData.content:
You like winter...But you hate being unable to warm your feet. 

You like summer...But you hate being so sweaty that you feel like melting in hell.

You like spring...But allergies!

You like autumn...but it's always sad and stressful.

Also, Are spring and autumn still a thing?

Nothing is perfect...

There's always a flaw to be found...

It was never about finding the perfect thing...

The perfect job...

The perfect person...

The perfect situation...

The perfect moment...

Or the perfect life...

It was always about finding things that you could live with, flaws and all...

Learning to appreciate their flaws...Or even love them.

So, Instead of wasting our lives looking for perfection, let's start accepting flaws.
Ours.
Theirs.

Let's appreciate life more...And let go of extremes...

Flaws are not the enemy...they're a wonderful part of the story...and it's time to embrace them.

postsData.content:
The Arkanoid Simulation shows how Gear.exe redefines what‚Äôs possible for Ethereum Mainnet onchain performance.

All with near-zero gas fees, NO fragmentation and NO latency ‚Üì

What is the Arkanoid Simulation?

It‚Äôs not just a game. It‚Äôs a high-load simulation designed to test onchain performance.

Each ‚Äúgame‚Äù involves intensive calculations‚Äîtracking ball physics, collisions, and game logic‚Äîall processed onchain.

Why does this matter?

- Ethereum struggles with latency and heavy computations due to its gas limits.
- Layer 2 solutions like Arbitrum improve scalability but inherit EVM performance limits and come with fragmentation.

On the other hand...

Gear.exe is an Ethereum network extension that executes multiple simulations in a single block with near-zero gas fees and comes without fragmentation.

The Setup:

We tested the same simulation on:
- Ethereum: Baseline test to measure performance and costs.
- Arbitrum EVM: Cheaper, but same gas logic as Ethereum.
- Arbitrum Nitro: Optimized with WASM, 1,000 iterations per block.
- Gear.exe: Parallel execution of 16 games in a single Ethereum block.

Why Gear.exe stands out:

- Runs 16 high-load simulations simultaneously in a single block.
- Near-zero gas costs and and low latency for massive computations.
- Drastically improved UX: avoids fragmentation and latency on user a side.
- Fully compatible with Ethereum (MetaMask, Etherscan).
- Network extension - value accrual on Ethereum mainnet.

Imagine the possibilities:

This simulation demonstrates that Gear.exe isn‚Äôt just for gaming‚Äîit‚Äôs a game-changer for any high-load computation on Ethereum mainnet.

‚Ä¢ DeFi protocols? Check.
‚Ä¢ Machine learning models? Check.
‚Ä¢ Real-time gaming? Check.

And we kept the receipts to prove it:

‚úíÔ∏èClaire M. DavisüñãÔ∏è
postsData.content:
If someone tells you to jump into self-care 
immediately after a layoff, either they've...

...never been laid off (without something lined up)
OR
aren't taking your situation as serious as it should be.

Either way, it's terrible advice.

Think of a LAYOFF like a burning house.

IF you're house is on fire:

It's shocking
100% an emergency
Going to hurt financially

It's absolutely NOT the time to:

>> to go get a massage
>> to take up goat yoga in your living room
>> to dance around and sing Lizzo's "Special" for a day and take your foot off the gas

And while self-care is important LATER -- it is NOT a priority when your wallpaper is curling and you're tapping doorhandles for heat on the way out.

Nope.

Not yet.

It IS time, however, to grab your 'go bag' and 'get outta that house.'

And by 'go bag' after a layoff, I mean 2 specific things:

1// YOUR CONTACTS
2// YOUR METRICS

Sit down and write out everyone you know,
grab your database that you developed,
download the numbers and
wins that you generated.

These things are your insurance policy for the future.
They will save you in that next interview with Smith & Nephew
when they ask you "so, how much revenue/volume growth did you achieve, and how?"

They'll be your lifeline after that computer is shut off and mailed back to Home Office when you're trying to network with those on the inside and sending thank you notes and reviews (Traction Clients, ikyk).

(and if you're on my email list, you'll soon find out  e x a c t l y  how to do this on Saturday, too. I've got you)

So grab a seat, a pen, and paper -- and write. it. all. down.

This is your Exit Plan.
Your Personal Escape Hatch.
Your Fire Squad at the Ready Should the Worst Happen.

And once you've done that
it's self-care time.

And hey,
if you know that you may need this 'go bag'
what's stopping you from gathering these things before su casa is aflame?

Take it from someone who's been through 5 of these.

Contacts
Metrics
Self-Care

(In that order)

xo
Claire

comments.commentText: Great analogy, Claire! Prioritizing actionable steps over immediate self-care is crucial after a layoff. Your insights are invaluable!

Take care of your mental health after losing your job, but secure all important data and contacts from your previous role before resting, Ô∏èClaire M. DavisÔ∏è. You likely will lose access to the data and contacts soon!

postsData.commentAdded: Great analogy, Claire! Prioritizing contacts and metrics after a layoff is crucial. Preparation truly is the best form of self-care! üëè

Innovation for Good: The Braille Smartwatch That‚Äôs Changing Lives. Over 285 Million+ people worldwide are visually impaired, yet most smart devices rely on screens. 

The Dot Watch bridges the gap, proving that innovation should be inclusive, not exclusive.

For years, the visually impaired relied on bulky, mechanical Braille watches or audio-based devices to check the time. But what if they could "feel" time in real-time‚Äîdiscreetly and effortlessly?

Instead of traditional watch hands or screens, the Dot Watch features a dynamic Braille display with four active cells that refresh seamlessly, allowing users to read the time, notifications, and even texts through touch.

 Beyond Timekeeping:

Reads messages, alarms, and notifications via Bluetooth
Offers tactile navigation for daily tasks
Lightweight, sleek, and stylish‚Äîno more clunky accessibility devices

 Technology should empower, not exclude. The Dot Watch is a step toward a future where accessibility isn‚Äôt an afterthought‚Äîit‚Äôs the foundation of innovation.

What other assistive technologies do you think need more attention?

When actions or behaviors are consistent over time, it fosters trust among individuals or within organizations.

Consistent effort towards a goal or objective increases the likelihood of success over time, as it maintains momentum and direction.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Enhances productivity:
Consistency in habits and routines helps streamline processes, leading to greater efficiency and productivity in both personal and professional life.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Establishes credibility:
Consistently delivering high-quality work or outcomes establishes credibility and reinforces one's reputation in a particular field or industry.

There has never been a better time for AI in field service. 

As long as you're leveraging smart diagnostics, hands-free workflows, and real-time assistance to empower technicians.

We‚Äôre seeing major advancements in AI-driven field service technology across multiple areas:

1) AI-powered diagnostics are getting smarter: Technicians can input symptoms or upload images/videos, and AI provides probable causes and solutions. This reduces guesswork, speeds up repairs, and improves first-time fix rates.

2) Voice-enabled workflows are streamlining operations: Hands-free interactions allow technicians to log updates, receive step-by-step instructions, and access safety checklists‚Äîall without stopping work.

3) Automation is eliminating inefficiencies: AI is optimizing scheduling, rerouting technicians in real time, and keeping customers informed without manual effort.

As AI capabilities expand, field service is becoming faster, more precise, and more efficient.

This is just the beginning of what‚Äôs possible.

I have 2 secret tricks I do with Zoom.

Both are easy and get WOWs from buyers.

I am running about 25 meetings per week right now.

Clear, strong, direct communication is important.

We use Zoom for meetings. Duh.



These 2 things both feel like they make a difference.


1. I make myself a "floating head" when I share my screen.

Check out the image in the post to see how.

Not sure why but EVERYONE comments on it.

It's just me in the corner of the screen with what I'm presenting.


2. I use captions when I can't understand someone.

It might be an accent, bad audio, etc.

But the real time captions help me actually be able to "listen" to someone.

Literally saved my life in a recent meeting with some French folks.

postsData.content:
‚ÄºÔ∏è TechBro Shares One Ugly Reality of Profit-driven AI that Led him to Walk Away ‚ÄºÔ∏è

Yes, this is one of the many aspects of the tech sector that is not being talked enough about. So here I am sharing one of the reasons I do not want to be part of it anymore.

Luckily, I never found myself in this ugly situation, since I have always been involved in the B2B AI sector.

But even then, I witnessed firsthand the lack of respect of your privacy amongst companies and investors, pushing ethics and your right at the bottom of the list of priorities.

At best, ethics is just a box-ticking exercise than a genuine strategy or priority. Look at DEI, for example, and how they messed it up.

If they truly believed in it, it would‚Äôve been much more than just a brainless and divisive box-ticking exercise.

If they truly believed in ethics or diversity, they wouldn‚Äôt have capitulated to the ‚Äúmasculinity‚Äù nonsense or behave like beta-men kissing the ring of some man-child overcompensating for something.

I know for a fact that many of my ex-investors would‚Äôve pushed me to join the current AI race to get the cash and attention regardless of consequences. But this is not the reason I dedicated my entire adult life to AI innovation since the latest 90s.

AI models are remarkable and extremely powerful tool to achieve some great business outcomes, as well as major social benefits.

And, no, they do not require giving away your privacy rights or copyrights, etc.

Believe me, you can do a hell of a lot more than using the multi-billion dollar models to summarise documents, ask for recipes, or ask it to automate some random tasks.

AI can literally change the world. One example that I like to use is DeepMind‚Äôs AlphaFold ‚Äî a smaller AI model that has revolutionised biotech forever. Yet, where is their spotlight and cash?

What I am sharing here is a one reality of tech that does not prioritise people, and certainly does not prioritise innovation. It‚Äôs cash, cash and more cash ‚Äî with loads of data on top (have you seen DOGE recently )

Still have doubts? Well, check the link on the comments of what OpenAI and Microsoft really mean by ‚ÄúAGI‚Äù ‚Äî you know, the super AI intelligence that apparently you need in your life (spoiler alert you don‚Äôt need it and it has nothing to do with intelligence).

Just a thought for you this weekend. Happy Friday Ô∏è

postsData.content:
An objection can feel like a slap in the face (if you don't know how to handle it)

How I handle top 10 sales objections:

Every objection is an opportunity for discovery - peel the onion.

1 ‚ÄúEmail me in 3 months"
- What will happen in 3 months?

2 ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not interested"
- Before I leave - Is <challenge> a priority right now? if not, what is?

3 ‚ÄúToo expensive‚Äù
- It sounds like you're comparing this to what you already have or just the value isn't there for you. Which one is it?

4 ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have the budget‚Äù
- Budget aside, is this even close to a priority for 2025?

5 ‚ÄúI‚Äôm locked into a contract with a competitor‚Äù
- Anything you‚Äôd want to improve with your current solution?

6 ‚Äútried it & it didn‚Äôt work for us‚Äù
- Could you tell me more about what didn‚Äôt work?

7 ‚ÄúWe just signed a contract with a provider‚Äù
- Would you want to explore other options before renewal, just to compare?

8 ‚ÄúWe already use a competitor‚Äù
- Would you be open to hearing 3 ways we differ?

9 ‚ÄúAll set for now‚Äù
- Just so I‚Äôm clear, what‚Äôs working well that you feel all set on?

10 I‚Äôm too busy right now
- Is there a better time, or should I send a quick summary by email?

Don't fight the objection, get to the real why.

That's the art of verbal judo.

How do you handle objections?

PS. I`m, follow me for tips on how to drive revenue from LinkedIn & Email

comments.commentText: Objections aren‚Äôt roadblocks‚Äîthey‚Äôre just detours to the real conversation. Ask the right question, and suddenly, "not interested" turns into "tell me more."
Neil Sarkar it‚Äôs one step from: ‚Äûhmm, tell me more‚Äù

postsData.name:
Drishti Sharma
Drishti Sharma
postsData.content:
I‚Äôm in my late 20s and have almost NEVER lived away from my parents.

Not because I couldn‚Äôt.
Not because I didn‚Äôt have opportunities.
But because I didn‚Äôt want to.

For the longest time, I thought independence meant breaking away ‚Äì
moving out, paying rent, doing everything solo.
That‚Äôs what we‚Äôve been conditioned to believe, right?

But independence isn‚Äôt about where we live.
It‚Äôs about the choices we make.

I‚Äôve lived both ways, I know what it feels like to be fully on my own.
And yet, I choose to stay with my family.
Not because I can‚Äôt function alone, but because I function better with them.

Honestly, living with family isn‚Äôt always easy. You pay a price for it ‚Äì sometimes in your mental peace, personal space, or lifestyle choices.

But the trade-offs? They‚Äôre worth it:

‚Üó My mom still ensures I eat properly (and yes, she brings me fruits while I work).
‚Üó I don‚Äôt have to think about laundry or changing bedsheets or whether there‚Äôs tea when I need it ‚Äì everything just happens.
‚Üó I save a lot on rent in a city like Mumbai, and I spend/invest that money where it actually matters without any guilt.
‚Üó Even travel expenses are significantly lower‚Äîanother bonus most people don‚Äôt talk about.

I‚Äôm building my career, growing my online community of 700k+, and scaling my content business‚Äîall while being supported by the very people who raised me.

Isn‚Äôt that a kind of privilege too?
Independence doesn‚Äôt have one definition.
For me, choosing to stay is its own kind of freedom.

Living with family might not be for everyone or every profession.
But the way the world glorifies moving out, rarely do we talk about what we gain when we choose to stay.

I guess we need to stop attaching our self-worth to the idea of moving out.

Do you think living with family holds you back or provides the support you need to grow?

comments.commentText: Society often pushes the narrative that we need to live alone to be independent, but your experience highlights how family support can actually enhance our growth. Kudos to you for making a conscious choice that aligns with your goals!

postsData.commentAdded: What a refreshing perspective! Independence truly comes in many forms. Its wonderful to see you thriving with a supportive foundation! üåü

Jordan Hollander
Jordan Hollander
postsData.content:
10 Leadership Lessons from Claudia Infante, Margaritaville CDO‚Äîrecent recipient of Hospitality Technology‚Äôs 2024 Lifetime Achievement Award 

Under her leadership, Margaritaville launched its perks loyalty program which attracted 350,000 members in less than two years! 

It generated more than $150M in revenue!

I had the privilege of sitting down with Claudia to explore Margaritaville‚Äôs tech stack in depth. Here are 10 leadership lessons I learned from her‚Äîand why I wholeheartedly agree with each one:

1Ô∏è‚É£ ‚ÄúTechnology should complement and optimize the human experience, not replace it.‚Äù

Yes. The right tech eliminates friction and empowers teams to focus on what truly matters: creating personal, memorable stays.

2Ô∏è‚É£ ‚ÄúBe adaptable and nimble in response to change.‚Äù

The most successful operators test, iterate, and pivot quickly‚Äîwhether responding to evolving guest preferences or adopting new technologies.

3Ô∏è‚É£ ‚ÄúCultivate a passionate and adaptable workforce.‚Äù

Teams that love what they do and can navigate new challenges deliver exceptional service, no matter the circumstances.

4Ô∏è‚É£ ‚ÄúDevelop a unique loyalty program that aligns with your brand identity.‚Äù

Emotional loyalty‚Äîbuilt through surprise perks and personalized experiences‚Äîfosters stronger guest connections than points ever could.

5Ô∏è‚É£ ‚ÄúChoose technology partners that align with your brand values and growth strategy.‚Äù

The best ones collaborate with you to solve problems, share your vision, and innovate alongside your team.

6Ô∏è‚É£ ‚ÄúRegularly evaluate your technology stack and make adjustments as needed.‚Äù

What worked yesterday may not work tomorrow. Regular reviews ensure your systems align with operational goals and keep pace with evolving guest needs.

7Ô∏è‚É£ ‚ÄúStrive for a balanced tech stack that caters to your specific needs.‚Äù

One size doesn‚Äôt fit all. Combine mandated systems with open solutions to keep operations efficient, flexible, and scalable.

8Ô∏è‚É£ ‚ÄúLeverage data visualization to gain insights and make informed decisions.‚Äù

Data isn‚Äôt useful if you can‚Äôt act on it. Real-time dashboards highlight trends and opportunities, helping teams make smarter, faster decisions.

9Ô∏è‚É£ ‚ÄúEmbrace AI strategically to enhance the guest experience and streamline operations.‚Äù

AI should enhance human interaction rather than replace it. Whether through predictive analytics or chatbots, the goal is to create seamless and personalized guest journeys.

 ‚ÄúEmpower your team with the right tools and training to focus on guest experience.‚Äù

Automation reduces the mundane, freeing your team to focus on what guests value most: genuine care and thoughtful service.

Claudia‚Äôs visionary leadership and commitment to innovation truly set a standard for excellence in hospitality. 
.
.

A rep recently asked me why I chose the path of Sales VP over being an individual contributor. "The stress is higher, and you could probably make more as a top performer," he said.

My answer? The deep fulfillment of coaching.

Nothing quite matches the satisfaction of seeing your guidance take root and flourish. Not just in closing a specific deal, but in shaping someone's entire career trajectory.

Last month, a rep I coached over a decade ago reached out. They shared how certain principles we discussed years ago are still cornerstone elements of their sales approach today. These moments - when you realize your impact extends far beyond quarterly numbers - are truly priceless.

This reinforced something I've always believed: The ROI of coaching isn't measured in immediate wins, but in the compound effect of transformed careers.

Starting next week, I'm doubling down on coaching conversations. Because sometimes the most valuable deals we close aren't measured in dollars, but in the lasting impact we have on others.

postsData.content:
You get cold called. It‚Äôs not a great time to talk.

You politely let the caller know and end the call.

Seconds later‚Äîring, ring‚Äîthey call back, pretending the line accidentally dropped. Then, before you know it, they start pitch-slapping you.

You‚Äôre thrilled, right? You drop everything, give them all the time in the world, and eagerly book a meeting.

Nope. None of us would react that way.

We‚Äôd be annoyed. Ignored. Frustrated. And we‚Äôd remember exactly why salespeople have a bad reputation with buyers. You‚Äôd be hanging up with fury and would likely block their number.

‚ÄòSales people don‚Äôt listen‚Äô.

The tale as old as time.

Yet, I recently saw a Sales Trainer on here suggest this is exactly what reps should do‚Äîbacked by a chorus of commenters cheering it on.

If this is what‚Äôs being taught, is it any wonder so many reps struggle to build pipeline?

Until we start putting ourselves in our prospect‚Äôs shoes, we‚Äôll keep failing to build trust and credibility with buyers.

comments.commentText: Nothing says ‚Äòtrust me‚Äô like ignoring a prospect‚Äôs ‚Äònot now‚Äô and calling back anyway. If we hate it as buyers, why teach it as sellers?
Neil Sarkar that was the question I was trying to ask but couldn‚Äôt think of it. Thanks Neil!

postsData.commentAdded: Great points! Empathy in sales is crucial. Understanding prospects needs can transform the approach and outcomes. Let‚Äôs prioritize listening!

postsData.content:
What is the Principle of Reciprocity? 

Have you heard, "If someone is good to me, I am good to them. I treat people the way they treat me"? This is the concept of the Reciprocity Principle.

For example, if someone does you a favor, you naturally feel the urge to return that favor when the time comes. This is how the Reciprocity Principle works.

Another example: You help your colleague meet their project deadline. Later, they agree to write a recommendation letter for you.

comments.commentText: The power of reciprocity! Giving value without expecting anything in return can lead to meaningful relationships and unexpected opportunities

postsData.name:
Frankie Russo
Frankie Russo
postsData.content:
Most people think the path from failure to success is a straight shot. It‚Äôs not.

It‚Äôs messy. It‚Äôs chaotic. It‚Äôs full of moments where you‚Äôre not sure if you‚Äôre on the verge of something great or completely off track.

But the magic isn‚Äôt in avoiding the struggle‚Äîit‚Äôs in what it teaches us.

Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned about this space in between:

1Ô∏è‚É£ The ‚ÄúAlmost‚Äù Moments

Those near-misses? They‚Äôre not failures‚Äîthey‚Äôre feedback. When I was building my first tech company, every ‚Äúalmost‚Äù showed us what our clients actually needed, not just what we thought they wanted.

2Ô∏è‚É£ The Beautiful Mess

This is where real growth happens. I call it ‚Äúproductive discomfort‚Äù‚Äîthose moments when you‚Äôre questioning everything. But that‚Äôs exactly where the breakthroughs hide.

3Ô∏è‚É£ The Pause

We‚Äôre told to hustle from failure to success, but there‚Äôs power in the pause. Sitting with what didn‚Äôt work, letting it teach you‚Äîsometimes the biggest leaps forward start by stepping back.

Why This Space Matters:
1. It‚Äôs where innovation is born.
2. It‚Äôs where resilience is built.
3. It‚Äôs where your weird becomes your superpower.

Success isn‚Äôt about skipping the messy middle‚Äîit‚Äôs about learning to navigate it.

What‚Äôs been your experience in this space between failure and success? I‚Äôd love to hear your stories.

comments.commentText: Your insights on navigating the chaotic journey from failure to success resonate deeply; it's in those "almost" moments that we uncover the true essence of growth.
Kshitij Mishra
It is indeed, Kshitij Mishra. It's how you learn how to improve and get better results.

I used to coach people through transition‚Äî and that messy middle is certainly hard to appreciate for most people! We just want to go from winter to summer in our lives‚Ä¶, forgetting that sometimes it still snows in May, but we‚Äôre still on our way! Love this Frankie!

postsData.content:
I remember when I first started on LinkedIn. I was posting regularly, connecting with people, and building my network. 

But despite all the activity, something felt off.

I wasn't seeing the results I expected.

I would see my post engagements, but then... nothing.

My profile views were low, and my connection requests were stagnant. I realized, I was neglecting my profile views.


Here‚Äôs what I learned:

 Profile Views are Your Digital Footprint.

‚Üí Every time someone views your profile, it‚Äôs an opportunity.
‚Üí Profile views are a signal that someone is interested in you. That‚Äôs the first step toward making a meaningful connection.

 Your Profile is Your First Impression.

‚Üí When someone clicks on your profile, that‚Äôs their first opportunity to learn about you.
‚Üí If your profile isn‚Äôt optimized, you‚Äôre losing a chance to build trust and show what you‚Äôre about.

 How to Get More Profile Views:

‚Üí Optimize your headline and summary. Make it clear, concise, and compelling.
‚Üí Post regularly and engage actively with others. Be visible.
‚Üí Use keywords that attract your ideal audience.

 Don‚Äôt Just Wait for Views, Encourage Them.

‚Üí When you engage in meaningful conversations, people are more likely to check out your profile.
‚Üí Every interaction is a chance for a new view.

 Take Action When You Get Views.

‚Üí When you see someone has viewed your profile, take the opportunity to send them a personalized message.
‚Üí Don‚Äôt just wait for them to connect with you, be proactive.


I used to neglect my profile views, but once I started focusing on them, the results came.

My profile views increased, and so did my connections. More importantly, the quality of my connections grew.


Stop neglecting them. Start using them to your advantage.



If you found it helpful Ô∏è & connect

Goldbach Secret Hack: Tens of Thousands of Dollars of Wins

Here's a secret strategy for those manual trading on Goldbach.

Analyze your entry using the 81 PO3 on the 5minute chart and on the 243 PO3 on the 1H chart

If you're going long AND the RB, OB, FVG or LV on both PO3 frameworks are in the same approximate positions, your entries will be scalpel and require tight stop losses (set at the low OR 0.111 Ext)

postsData.content:
resilience+Rise Podcast: A conversation with Kal Dosanjh: Part 1

From the Streets to Solutions:‚Äôs Mission to Empower Youth

A single encounter with a 15-year-old struggling with addiction led to a powerful realization‚Äîthese kids aren‚Äôt just statistics; they are products of their environment, in need of support and guidance.

This week on the Resilience+Rise podcast, we sit down with Kal Dosanjh, a veteran police officer with 25 years of service, including 8 years patrolling Vancouver‚Äôs Downtown Eastside. His journey from witnessing the harsh realities of street life to creating impactful solutions is one you won‚Äôt want to miss.

Kal's story isn't just about law enforcement; it's about understanding the root causes of crime and creating real, lasting change.

Kal shares his experiences in one of North America's most challenging environments, describing the complex socio-economic factors that contribute to the open-air drug market and the cycle of violence. He talks about the "perfect storm" of social housing, mental health challenges, and organized crime that plagues the Downtown Eastside. But more importantly, he shares the pivotal moment that shifted his focus from reactive policing to proactive community building.

This realization led Kal to found the KidsPlay Foundation, a registered charity dedicated to providing youth with positive alternatives. He explains the six streams of KidsPlay's work ‚Äì education, sports, mentorship, environment, clinical counseling, and community patrol ‚Äì and shares inspiring stories of kids whose lives have been transformed. From educational field trips to sports programs and mentorship opportunities, KidsPlay offers a lifeline to vulnerable youth, helping them develop valuable skills and make positive choices. Kal's powerful "mahout" metaphor perfectly illustrates the importance of instilling positive values early in life.

Join me, Thomas Scaria, ultra-marathoner and resilience coach, as I talk with Kal about his incredible journey, the challenges facing inner-city youth, and the transformative power of hope and opportunity. This is a conversation that will leave you inspired and motivated to make a difference.

Tune in to the Resilience+Rise podcast now! (Full Podcast & connection in the comments)

postsData.content:
The 12-Month Mirage: Why Your Data Supplier's "Verification" Calls Are Costing You Sales

Many businesses rely on data suppliers who promise "verified" business information, often claiming to call each business to confirm details. But what if this "verification" happens only once a year, or even less frequently or even done where all the information was asked to whoever happened to answer the phone at that moment?

We recently encountered a client facing this very issue. Their data provider assured them of regularly updated and accurate contact information, based on these periodic calls. However, their sales team was struggling, encountering a frustratingly high number of outdated contacts. They were chasing businesses that had closed, contacts who had moved on, and generally wasting valuable time and resources.

Our team conducted a complimentary data audit, uncovering a significant disconnect between the promised verification and the reality on the ground. Over 23% of the records represented businesses that were no longer operating. The accuracy of the remaining contacts, supposedly "verified" within the past year, hovered around a disappointing 80%. This highlighted a critical flaw: a single phone call, conducted perhaps once a year, is simply insufficient to maintain data accuracy in today's rapidly changing business environment. Businesses close, people move jobs, and information becomes outdated quickly. A snapshot taken once a year is hardly a reliable reflection of the current landscape.

This situation echoes our experiences when we acquiredwho in addition to their own fleet data re-sold a 3rd parties own tele-verified data. It reinforces a crucial point: data accuracy is not a one-time event; it's an ongoing process.

We helped our client address these data challenges by thoroughly cleansing their database, removing dissolved businesses and verifying the remaining contacts through more robust and frequent methods using our own technology which updates our entire database every 30 days using our machine led process. The impact was immediate and positive. Their sales team, now equipped with accurate, up-to-date data, experienced a substantial increase in productivity and lead conversion.

This experience exposes the myth of the annual "verification" call. It's not just inefficient; it's misleading. Relying on such infrequent checks creates a false sense of security, leading businesses to believe they have accurate data when they‚Äôre working with outdated and unreliable information.

We understand that data accuracy requires continuous effort. Our 30-day, machine-led process provides ongoing data refinement, ensuring that our clients always have access to the most up-to-date and accurate information. We empower businesses to move beyond the limitations of outdated verification practices and embrace data-driven strategies that deliver real results.
